title: Former mayor of Brighton dies age 72
text:
Balcombe celebrates permission to build solar park Promoted stories 
To jeers and hisses from the Tory faithful, she invited then prime minister John Major to visit Brighton’s recession-hit hostels and community advice centres, as well as its royal palaces. 
Again proving her willingness to ruffle feathers for her beliefs, she sparked furious debate in 1995 by arguing that people who were dying with inhumane levels of pain should be “put down”. Her view evolved to believing in the right to choose. 
Mr Sweeting said he thought she was too ill to understand that the Assisted Dying Bill she campaigned for had failed to get through parliament in September, adding it would have "upset her very much" to know. 
Outside of politics, her work included secretarial work for several large organisations and until recently she produced Brighton and Sussex Take Heart Group’s magazine. 
She also used to work typing students’ dissertations, often working late into the night to make sure they met their deadlines. Share article 
She loved photography and jazz music, Mr Sweeting said. 
He added: “I cannot really sum her up. To me she was just Gill. We always used to say in relation to certain things you did not need both of us, because we both held the same views.” Promoted Stories Former mayor of Brighton Gill Sweeting dies age 72 Sorry, an error occurred.
